messageBody:
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> Jason Rogers wrote:
>
> > try {
> > articleProvider.findArticleById("foobar");
> > fail("Expected NoObjectFoundException);
> > } catch (Exception e) {
> > assertSame(e.getClass(), NoObjectFoundException.class);
> > // or whatever else seems appropriate (eg. testing getMessage() or
> > other attribute)
> > }
>
> Wow. I haven't seen that one before. It's growing on me, since it
> handles the "unexpected exception" failure without the whole
> Error/Failure confusion.
>
> I should think, though, that
> assertTrue(NoObjectFoundException.class.isInstance(e)) is required,
> though, so that you can throw a subclass of the exception without
> failing the test. Perhaps that has just never been a problem for you.

Yes. That was a DeliberateLazyMoment
(http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?DeliberateLazyMoment), as my follow-up might
suggest. I actually don't remember a time when I have tested for
instanceof or isInstance(), although it's possible I have. I usually
test the getMessage() to make sure it references my "inputs".

A common example might be something like:

public void testInstantiation() {
try {
ApplicationConfiguration.instanceFor(badParameter(...),
goodParameter(...));
fail("should have thrown IllegalArgumentException because
<exceptionReason dealing with badParameter>");
} catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
assertStringContains(e.getMessage(), <exceptionReason dealing
with badParameter>);
}
try {
ApplicationConfiguration.instanceFor(goodParameter(...),
badParameter(...));
fail("should have thrown IllegalArgumentException because
<exceptionReason dealing with badParameter>");
} catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
assertStringContains(e.getMessage(), <exceptionReason dealing
with badParameter>);
}

assertNotNull(ApplicationConfiguration.instanceFor(goodParameter(...),
goodParameter(...)));
}

--
Jason Rogers
